text: [Music]
I've learned this the hard way because
when I took over as chief executive of
Reuters in
2001, not only was there what seemed at
the time to be a significant recession
in financial services, but it was just
after 911 and Reuters itself was not in
good competitive condition and I had to
take out a lot of cost in a hurry and
had to do it in not a particularly
nuanced way. So we took out something
like 5,000 people out of what was at one
point 19,000
um at Reuters and that was probably the
most difficult thing I've ever done. um
having to do
that has conditioned in some way the way
I've managed ever since in that I never
want to let the business go so off the
rails that one would need such an
extraordinary program again to do it. Um
the only way I know to motivate people
through a period like that and it's not
just everyone else it's about motivating
myself and my managers as well is you
got to believe in the goal. I mean, we
felt those of us who came through that
period 2001 2003 at Reuters that this
150 year old company was a force for the
good deserve to live to see another day
and although it was very painful to
often say goodbye to friends in the
process um we had to focus on how do you
make a 150y old company how do you give
it another 150year year license and how
do you create a stable employer for all
the families that stay and sometimes you
need to do that sort of tough medicine
but it ain't a lot of
fun. Why do we have to have such a boom
and bust cycle? I think the US economy
is sort of uniquely sympathetic to the
lay on a lot of people and then take
them out during difficult times. Um
obviously some of the more socialized
countries um have have more stringent
rules about um laying folks off. The
downside then is you don't add jobs. So
if you look at what's happening in
Europe right now, it's all of the
contractors are in deep trouble because
people haven't wanted to add permanent
jobs in Germany, in France, in Italy, um
because it's hard to get rid of them. So
I'm not sure what's the best political
answer because if you make it too
difficult to eliminate posts, um nobody
ever wants to add them. you know, if I
had to know that this is a job that'll
be with the company for 50 years, um I'm
going to take a lot longer to create
that new job or maybe I'll do it on a
contract basis rather than bringing on a
permanent employee. Um you know, our
experience here, let's take Thompson
Reuters. Um right now through this
recession um we have been eliminating
some positions but that's far more
driven by the logic of the integration
of the acquisition of Reuters by
Thompson than by the recession itself.
So we have been careful over the last
couple of years in part I think because
of my difficult experience at Reuters
and Thompson's always been an efficient
company as well. So the jobs that are
going by and large are the jobs that
were the overlap. Um and we haven't had
to announce sort of special purpose
layoffs um other than in you know very
particular uh circumstances.
